title: Great environment
pros: Supportive team and great benefits. Fast-paced environment with high expectations, but strong career growth potential.
cons: Leadership can be demanding, but overall a solid company for ambitious professionals.

title: Good company
pros: Good benefits, good location. Good company outings
cons: Not a lot of growth opportunities

title: Great Place To Work
pros: Excellent management that is very encouraging and treats everyone more than just an employee
cons: Difficult to move positions horizontally within firm

title: Great company to work for
pros: Very respectful work environment for a first job. Manage assets at the highest level.
cons: Very admin heavy work. Not involved in any decision making.

title: Positive Momentum
pros: Moving in the right direction
cons: Tough headwinds the past few years, but the tide feels like it's turning,,,

title: Good company
pros: People and building are great
cons: Excessive workload and pressure to hit more and more goals

title: Decent entry-level pay and benefits, but the company is frustratingly stuck in the past.
pros: When you first join BXP in an entry-level position, you'll find that the pay, benefits, and work experience you'll receive are decent compared to other companies in this field. Staff, leadership and culture were better than average in the Prudential Tower office.
cons: Your growth at BXP is very dependent on office politics, and in many cases I found leadership neglecting many talented individuals who wanted to grow internally, likely just because they weren't friendly enough with the right people. Likewise, it is not uncommon for some departments to treat their entry-level staff with little respect, so be prepared to develop some thick skin. Leadership in some regions barely lead at all, and prefer to gossip amongst themselves rather than address any problems they have with their colleagues. While it is certainly is your own responsibility to show drive, ambition and commitment in your role, I found it a rarity for leadership to bring those attributes out of entry-level staff. As for pay and bonuses, don't expect much drastic change unless you somehow will yourself into a leadership role. While the base pay is decent, bonuses and raises for entry-level positions are frustratingly low, and are not competitive compared to other positions in this field.

title: Property Management Coordinator
pros:
- Good benefits 
- Fair salary
cons:
- No diversity and inclusion
- Lack of communication

title: Nice place to work
pros:
Excellent employer sponsored benefits
Room for career growth
cons: Nothing to mention as of now

title: Your department really determined it all
pros:
Benefits Package
Lots of Events
cons: Environment can feel stale, but the amenities for the job were spectacular.

pros: Environment is dynamic and fun.
cons: Over time opportunities are limited.

title: Its a good start
pros: people, location, pay, and the atmosphere
cons: it can get long hours at times

title: Good Company
pros:
Work life balance
Interesting work
Great people
cons: Need to get your own work from home setup

title: Property Management
pros: BXP is a great place to work and they have done an excellent job hiring great people.
cons: Old school mentality that limits work life balance.

title: Top CRE firm
pros: Strong leadership, brilliant and engaged team, premier assets
cons: Tough time in the market

title: I personally had a great time
pros: I know other offices had a lot of drama, but when I worked in the Santa Monica offices, I loved it. I loved my crew, my work load wasn't so bad, I felt appreciated and valued as an employee and coworker. My ideas were actually listened to, I felt included. I considered this job my "unicorn" - rare and may never be found again.
cons: My position required me to be able to wear many hats, this isn't a complaint, the complaint of this is that other managers from other offices felt like they had control over my duties as well (marketing mostly, from the San Francisco office)and it caused a polite tug of war between them and my supervisor. To be fair, my duties weren't that clear and I was to assist with everything, but I was encouraged to set boundaries.

title: Company is not what is used too
pros: - Free lunches. (pizza) - Prime locations - Free parking onsite in congested city for weekend visits. - 401K - Work life balance - During pandemic, the company sent everyone home and paid everyone without individuals using PTO for months, on top of it, they let individuals roll over unused vacation. - If management is on your side, you conquer the world.
cons: - Pay. Gosh, this place does not pay competitively. I worked over 10+ years, Specifically under the property management area, the bloodline on daily activities. I saw employees from all positions come and go. The company is not what is used too, The reason I stayed so long was because of the work life balance I had and certain type of people I worked along were wonderful. I remember those days when you use to sit down at the Class A restaurants with managers to enjoy lunch on a quarterly basis. Now? order pizza and eat it at the conference room. Upper management promotes based on "likeness" and not on quality or experience. A lot of upper management credentials are lower than the newly hired personnel (shh! you don't know that). Great people slowly leaving, company founders slowly retiring, a new era is coming. There is rivalry within management and not a team environment. There is rivalry because the meat is too small, There is no room for advancement. Pay is not equal. The only way to stay alive is to mingle with the right management, A.K.A corporate game. If you are here for advancement, or to learn, this is not the place, if you want to retire or play corporate game, apply. The reason the company remains somewhat competitive, is because of the few original people are still onboard, executive management is what does the heavy lifting and their core buildings in prime locations.

title: great company
pros: Great people, team collaboration, best building in the state
cons: We work alot but that is because we are the best in the business

title: Great Company
pros: Development program is very good. Great people.
cons: There are slow periods. Need to keep yourself busy.

title: Negative
pros: Colleagues are hard working and nice people
cons: Leadership is lazy, selfish and unrealistic, awful work life balance, insufficient staffing levels, stingy WFH rules, and commercial real estate is in decline.

title: Great Company that is changing for the better
pros: This firm tends to promote from within. Company is resilient financially and leadership is wise as to not take unnecessary risks. New Regional Head is really shaking things up for the better.
cons: No remote work options allowed to most employees, but VPs and Regional Office staff apparently partake. Furthermore office activities held outside of the office are only allowed to Regional Office staff.

title: Individual Company
pros: -Good pay and benefits -opportunities to work with upper level management -fast paced environment
cons: -incredibly corporate environment (not necessarily a con, just know that it is) -high stress environment - people are in a place to throw each other under the bus

title: Hard to get what you deserve
pros: The location is quite fun. I love working with customers, especially the tourists.
cons: Getting your benefits and correct pay is like pulling teeth. At this level employees are treated very poorly. Standing up for yourself will get you fired. Dealing with the homeless population that are looking to get out of the elements can be challenging and dangerous.

title: Things are Looking up
pros: Engaged employer who provides excellent benefits.
cons: It's a long walk down the stairs when the fire alarm goes off.

title: Entry Level- Property Management Coordinator
pros: Great community, beautiful location. Very easy work-life balance.
cons: It can get repetitive. Have to also be an "office manager.."

title: Interesting work but management is TOXIC
pros: You’ll learn a lot about accounting and property management. The team itself is solid - pretty helpful, nice, overall good and smart people. Made some good connections and friends. Benefits are awesome but pay/bonus is below market.
cons: Micromanaging, bullying, gaslighting, favoritism - all for below market pay. Management is toxic and can be downright mean. Stay away from the SF accounting department if you can. There are other property management companies in the city that will treat you better. Also minimal opportunity to get promoted unless you’re one of managements favorites.

title: Quality Product, Rigid Policies
pros: Well established company, financially stable, premier properties
cons: inflexible and rigid policies, challenging or no remote work opportunities

title: Paralegal
pros: Great company and good benefits
cons: No cons, generally a very good company to work for.

title: Great people to work with
pros: Substantial pay, helpful managers and friendly colleagues, many social events, and great office location.
cons: Sometimes lack of WLB, especially during end of every quarter.

pros:
Coworkers are nice
Decent benefits
Livable wage
cons: Promotion Track only for certain roles

title: Great Place to Work
pros: Great company with good benefits good structure and good management.
cons: Unfortunately they are not remote work friendly probably because they are in the commercial real estate space but still unfortunate.

title: Great
pros: Excellent workplace, would highly recommend it.
cons: None come to mind. It was great.

pros: This is a good place to work
cons: No work life balance quarter end

title: Great beginning
pros: Good office great people good area
cons: Low starting pay and stuff

title: Great people and place to work
pros: Pay is decent, lots of great people, and fun events at the town center
cons: I was laid off due to someone with seniority being internally transferred to my property after their property was sold.

title: Pretty good
pros: Team building, experience, schooling available and much more
cons: Lack of advancement and old views concerning work from home

title: Great place to work
pros: Good And decent pay , could be better but can be discussed. Comfortable place to work Friendly staff , no office politics which is really great Work , get paid and go home I love it .
cons: They need a streamlined training process . Most people get under trained and takes time to learn easy things that could be done within first 3 months in the job .

title: Great for career development
pros: Great leadership, experienced staff. Excellent
cons: Location location location location location

title: SENIOR MGR'S ARE DISENGUOUS
pros: Class A properties in prime real estate locations can give you good experience in commercial real estate. Lots of structure.
cons: Senior managers are primarily men who promise a lot to lure you to the job but then are not true to their word. Never a thank you for meeting and exceeding the position expectations. Never ask questions, propose alternate ways of doing things because their egos will shut you down. Its there way or the highway.

title: Good company
pros: Good company and people. Work life balance is there
cons: They could probably pay a little more in the property management department

title: Boston Properties - Traditional Work Environment
pros: Job stability, networking with tenants and external clients
cons: 5-day work week, conservative company

title: Love working here
pros: Treated very well by everyone
cons: There are no cons at Boston Properties

title: Old Fashioned Company, Which Also Kinda Made it Great
pros: Good Salary/Benefits, Clear Expectations, Low Drama. No cool-aid to drink, everybody has a family they love and want to get home to. This is work as work. Sure, some people have made it their whole life (and there are plenty of exciting opportunities) but there isn't the pressure that I found in start-ups to live and breath the company fervor and work crazy hours (though some people did) to prove your devotion. Personally I prefer the cut and dry straightforwardness of this steady and stalwart company. The company also had a great group mentality about projects--everybody got to go on tours of buildings, hear the exciting news at the monthly floor meetings, enjoy the perks of the exciting developments BxP vanguards. It was a fantastic company to be a part of--you felt (and could physically see!) the amazing building projects you were a part of.
cons: Low tech (sometimes frustratingly so), not much mobility, often impersonal. The vacation/maternity leave policies are woefully outdated.

title: Pretty Good
pros: Great place to make connections and get your foot in the door.
cons: Pretty dated and old school when it comes to company culture and technology.

title: AMAZING PEOPLE
pros: Most amazing, talented, diverse, dynamic group of people.
cons: Honestly, don’t have much negative to say I’m not easy one please

title: Good exposure, but don't stay too long
pros: Good benefits including a 6% 401k match and $100/month towards your commuter pass. Good exposure to various aspects of the industry.
cons: Constant turnover in the Corporate office. 9 of the 12 HR staff left within the span of one year, which should tell you something. Diversity initiatives are performative at best. Unapproachable upper management. Pay is not competitive. Little room for advancement. Admin Assistants are treated more like servants than team members (depending on your department). I told my direct manager that someone close to me had passed away. The following week she asked me, "Why are you so miserable?" and implied that my attitude was a problem. After a series of similar comments where this person made me feel subhuman, I brought my concerns to HR, where I felt that I was not being heard and my concerns were dismissed as being a miscommunication. I assure you, there was no miscommunication. She is just an awful human and truly a wolf in sheep's clothing.

title: Ok, but could be better
pros: Great 401K, holidays, time off. Health insurance used to be better but that is pretty much everywhere now. Employee perks are great. Some of the managers are really great to work with. It is a great company, but some things need to change.
cons: - People that do great are rarely recognized, the recognition always goes to the manager that didn't do anything. - Won't promote from within to people that deserve it, think that you are nothing without a bachelors degree even though you have more on the job experience than someone who has a bachelors off the street. - Pile a lot of extra work on without getting paid for what you truly do. - Pay isn't all that great. - Micromanagement, higher management treat lower level employees like they don't know what they are doing.

title: Ehhhh
pros: The benefits are pretty great. Some of the professional staff are really friendly and great to work with. Your role is fairly clearly delineated. There is a gym in the building and you're permitted to exercise on your lunch. They are also fairly flexible with your schedule if you have special circumstances. They also provide a commuting stipend which is awesome because it's right next to the Foggy Bottom metro station.
cons: As administrative staff, you are treated very differently than the professional staff. If you're 5 minutes late, you are reprimanded. If you complain or speak to your supervisor about a problem, not much will happen in the way of resolution. There is no where to grow from an administrative position. Some of the other administrative staff are wonderful people who are really enjoyable to work with but others are unbearable to be around and offensive and have driven more than one person to leave the company.

title: Formerly a great company
pros: Benefits are very good and there are a lot of wonderful people
cons: Hiring process is so slow that good candidates are lost to other offers. Pay is low with minimal 1.5-2% annual raises. Work load varies by department as do benefits like summer Fridays which are not available to all. Company prefers to move employees to new positions internally rather than hire from outside to avoid having to pay higher (market) salaries

title: Great Place to Work.... Just not SF Accounting Dept.
pros: Great benefits package. Many really wonderful people. Wonderful location. Decent pay.
cons: Micro-managed to the point of forcing employees to quit. Toxic is a word that nearly every person who is NOT management uses to describe the department.

title: Eh take it or leave it - Good Resume Addition
pros: Big bonus in February, never had layoffs. Large company recognition when seeking employment elsewhere - not hard to find a better job with BP on your resume.
cons: Extremely cliquey. If you’re not in the clique your probably being talked about. No communication between supervisor and employee. Everyone works in a silo no structure in place for collaboration or self improvement. Large turn around of employees for certain departments which slows down work because you have to train new employees on procedures or process. Management fails to address employee complaints about work environment.

title: Former Customer Service Representative
pros: Great support from coworkers/management. Flexible schedule. Opportunity to develop strong customer service skills in an environment that can be intensely demanding and very laid back all in the same day. They had a GREAT orientation process. After training, I felt very well equipped for the job, very familiar with the center that I would be representing, and even got to enjoy a free Skywalk tour as part of the training procedure.
cons: The nature of the Customer Service Representative position can be challenging as you are often the first person that issues are brought to. The traffic flow to the CS desk can fluctuate greatly throughout the day and the stress of the job can often fluctuate in sync with the traffic pattern.

title: Property Accountant
pros: Decent pay, great benefits, individual office for each property accountant, summer Fridays at 3 pm, BXP lunch for employees to get together once a month, free snacks & hot beverages. Managers have been working with the company more than 15 years; they know every detail of work and hands-on for the team.
cons: Need to re-structure for training.

title: Great company with a solid strategy
pros: Highly stable company with a solid business strategy. Arguably the best in its business. The people are extremely bright and friendly and if you are looking for experience in real estate you couldn't work for a better company. Good work/life balance.
cons: The actual office space is awful and old-school. Unfortunately BXP's work environment itself is still stuck in 1990. Ability to work remotely, which seems standard at any job these days, is not generally encouraged or supported as well as an option...... Guess they need to make sure their office buildings stay full!

title: Prepare to be Mirco-Managed
pros: Great benefits and friendly atmosphere, exposure to high end assets. 3PM fridays during the summer is great. The company offers other perks to get to know one another.
cons: Training is non-existent, management's ways of reviewing things is by micromanaging their staff. My team was once called into a room to point out to the rest of the team what a person did wrong/right. That is no way of providing constructive criticism. These processes needs to be revamped with more of a thought process.

title: Great Company
pros: Decent pay, good benefits, opportunity to promote within the company.
cons: Seems to be a minimum of 2.5 years on average before you are able to promote. When I first interviewed I was told that BP really likes to hire from within but quickly learned that many assistant property manager and property manager positions end up being filled from outside the company. Another con is that I feel it is a very hierarchal company where you feel like you are expected to walk on eggshells and act/dress a certain way in front of certain higher-ups. I guess I am not used to that from other companies I have worked for in the past.

title: Exceptional real estate developer
pros: Talented and driven colleagues, inclusive environment, flat/lean organization, accessible leadership that has its employees best interests in mind, tons of responsibility, outstanding learning opportunities by working on some of the most complex projects.
cons: Physical office environment is dated but this is a minor drawback; savings here roll into fantastic perks, benefits, educational programs, salary/bonuses, expenses, etc. Somewhat of an unsustainable workload at the top of the real estate cycle.

title: Caring Company
pros: The benefits are impeccable. High quality medical/dental/vision with low premiums. The 401(k) match vests immediately and is you get 6% on a 3% contribution. There are also professional development and tuition opportunities.
cons: - Flexibility such as remote work and flexible scheduling (depending on which department you work in) - First-year PTO - Dress code

title: Various
pros: I think the best reason to work here is the exposure to large scale projects and investments. The people are bright and the history of the company's leadership had been good.
cons: There can be a little complacency driven by the tenure of senior employees and the relatively static nature of the business. Those seeking an entrepreneurial environment will find themselves frustrated by the rigid nature of a a large public real estate company

title: Respected company in industry, no room for career growth
pros: Competent colleagues Great name on resume
cons: No opportunity for career growth Horrible pay for volume and complexity of work $3000+ yearly parking when the company owns the garage Tons of turnover in certain departments/roles

title: Great company; hopefully getting better
pros: The benefits are pretty great. The professional staff are really friendly and great to work with. Your role is fairly clearly delineated. They provide a commuting stipend which is awesome because it's right next to the Foggy Bottom metro station.
cons: As administrative staff, you are treated very differently than the professional staff. Hopefully that's getting better with changes in management. There is nowhere to grow from an administrative position.

title: Terrible managers
pros: - nice office space - successful company who prides themselves at being the best at what they do - supportive of development and promote within
cons: micromanagers running certain departments. looking at what time you get to your desk, what time you leave for lunch, when you leave for the day, etc. not a laid back envirnoment at all. very stuffy mens club.

title: small changes could go a long way
pros: exciting projects and properties in and around the city. great office locations, good coworkers, decent atmosphere.
cons: not very focused on good employees and keeping them except for certain areas. old school views that aren't helping the company tap into the current job seekers or keep the younger employees. low salary for lower level positions.

title: Manage your expectations
pros: The compensation is competitve with the general market. The location is spectacular with many amenities and restaurants nearby. Workload is very reasonable for financial-type firm
cons: Can be overly analytical and slow with regards to personnel promotions/hiring. There tends to be a lot of energy spent for CYA instead of just resolving problems.

title: IS department is very toxic
pros: - Buildings are the best in class - Office closes at 3 pm on Summer Fridays - Decent medical/dental insurance although wageworks FSA is the worst part. - Monthly commuter contribution to employee - Good 401k
cons: IT Department is very toxic environment. There are a lot of issues with IS Management. The IT department has a top/down mentality and this mentality comes from the very top management in IS. This mentality of the management prohibits growth and it is not collaborative. If someone offer an alternative, that idea will not be welcomed. The IS environment is infectious and is driven by IS leadership. In my view the networking team and the help desk teams do not work well together and it has a trickle down effect that negatively impacts the department. The leadership in network services are actually engineers promoted as managers. In fact they shouldn’t have been promoted as managers as they are not very people oriented. They lack managerial qualities. All the important technical work would be actually done by them and only irrelevant and not much visible projects would be given to the Engineers. They travel around to other regions under the disguise of work and spent time in conferences like RSA, EMCWorld and VMworld and do not give the engineers the opportunity to go either of these events or to these regions. The IS leadership has major trust issues and would not give work to anyone they do not trust. There is no training provided by the company and they expect you to complete projects with technology that no one has any idea. Also Boston Properties does not allow work from home even on inclement weather conditions. Also they pay is not good. No paternity leaves and maternity leave is just outdated. The company is very much old school. Its very much a 60’s environment. Also the HR department does not work for employees rather on behalf of executives. Complaints made to the HR department against the senior Leadership always falls on deaf ears.

title: Fantastic company
pros: Loyalty to employees, great work atmosphere. Buildings are the best in class and the company is fair and honest in all it's dealings. Every co-worker I come in contact with is very proud of what we do, how we do it and the results we get.
cons: Dress code; ties and jackets required except in the summer. Most of our clients waer "business casual" and sometimes we are "out of place" in our suits.

title: For a large corporation, Boston Properties takes great care of its employees.
pros: They are very flexible with scheduling. They are meticulous about gathering data/feedback from employees. The pay is good for the position. They offer a very eco-conscious workplace.
cons: Because it is a large corporation, it can be difficult to get things done quickly. There isn't much contact between upper management and the customer service team.

title: Unfriendly and Very Old School Type Office
pros: Free lunch - food trucks Great location - close to SF Ferry Building and BART Decent medical/dental Decent snacks and free good coffee/espresso Monthly $100 commuter contribution to employee Close early on Fridays from last Friday in June to first Friday in Sept
cons: Felt like a bug under a microscope. Management and other coworkers watched when I came in, what I did at my desk, when and how many times I looked at my cell phone, how many times I went to use the bathroom, when I went to lunch, what I ate for lunch and when I left to go home. If you came in 5-8 minutes late, you were warned and then written up. You had a strict schedule of 8-5 and if you decided you wanted to work a different schedule such as work 7:30-4:30 or 8-5 with an hour lunch or 7:30-4:00 or 8:00-4:30 or 8:30-5:00 and take a 30 minute lunch, it wasn't allowed and you got written up if you changed your time. Very strict dress code even for a place where you never met with the tenants or clients! If you needed to go to a doctor's appointment, you had to use a sick day. Of course if you were new, you don't have any sick days for 90 days but yet you are forced to pay for benefits that you cannot use. Don't micromanage your employees so much. Have you noticed you have a high turn over for your support staff? Pay is lower than the market rate. Archaic systems with having to obtain multiple signatures in person instead of using a computer system for approvals. Very old school atmosphere and very cliquey too. Very unfriendly office culture.

title: Formal, old school ways company
pros: Good benefits, interesting properties.
cons: Upper management treats lower level employees very poorly. Not a lot of confidence is given to employees they are doing good job. The annual review process is painful, long, and drawn out. Everything in this company is very formal. Not a lot of what is preached is practiced.

pros: Good benefits and properties but that's about it. Premier locations but the salary lacks significantly
cons: Impossible to move up. Positions are filled based on relationships of higher management and their friends. No recognition of work or basis for salary increases.

title: I enjoyed it very much.
pros: - Very pleasant office to work in - Great guidence from upper management - Great 401k program - Salary is great
cons: - I didn't ike how serious it could be at times - There were really no outlets for creativety - Some of my co-workers were very unpleasent

title: People have nothing better to do than to complain
pros: 401K match, Getting out at 3Pm on Fridays, 4 weeks vacation
cons: Workloads are unmanageable and managers know it and do not care. Old and stuffy atmosphere. Other departments have nothing better to do than to complain about others work/conduct.

title: Boston Properties
pros: Boston Properties always goes about their work in the most professional manner possible. Dotting every "i" and crossing every "t".
cons: Extremely corporate. It's either Sarbanes-Oxley or paranoid management but half of your time seems to be spent preparing for a future internal audit.

title: Property Manager
pros: Team, structure, upper management are supportive. benefits are top notch. If you're not happy with your current boss/company you will like this company/culture.
cons: Pay not at their peers. Going to lose some good people if they don't change their ways.

title: Assistant Property Manger
pros: Best in class benefits. Match 401k 6%
cons: Difficult to move up within company. Tend to hire from the outside. Salary is not on par with peers in the industry. Many within company feel same way.

title: Great company...few opportunities
pros: You will never find better people to work with than at Boston Properties. Leaving the people is the hardest part about leaving the company.
cons: There is no room for growth for the administrative staff, unless you moved into Property Management. There is little flexibility with hours.

title: Chief Engineer
pros: 401k, bonus, high exposure to industry professionals.
cons: Very Little growth opportunity unless you come in on the ground floor. Management expectations are high yet offer no real training. You will be expected to do not only your job but other people's job as well. Compensation does not always match the work load

title: an OK company
pros: The environment is pretty laid back
cons: The company does not promote from within. They are hesitant to promote women. Many upper level management are retired cops who just want to collect a second income, and don't really want to do work.

title: Typical Corporate Desk Job
pros: -Great office location in downtown DC - Staff is friendly and polite -Good benefits package (including monthly commuter allowance, stock purchase discount, 401k managed by T-Row Price)
cons: - Communication between department and corporate staff needs to be improved -Not much upward mobility for administrative staff - Little to no training or onboarding upon starting a new position

title: Great Company with great benefits
pros: Great company with great benefits. I have worked for this company for a number of years and really appreciate a company that values it's employees.
cons: I don't have too many cons. Most of their property in the NJ market is in Princeton, which makes for a tough commute if you don't live in the area.

title: It's alright, it's a job dont let them tell you how great a career it'll be
pros: Benefits are pretty good, insurance is pricy IMO, 401k matching
cons: Incompetent leadership and management teams. They make so much money and tell you about it in the quarterly meetings, but raises were a bit underwhelming.

title: Decent Company
pros: Great benefits. 401k matched 200%. Opportunity to get up to 4 weeks vacation. Fun group to work with.
cons: Upper Management doesn't seem to care about employees' work/personal life balance. Still seems like an old mans club- maternity leave bare minimum, senior executives all male, etc. Not a ton of room for growth.

title: Property Accountant
pros: Good benefits, pay and location.
cons: Upper management doesn't pay attention to your feedback. It's a million dollars company but they're still very cheap. Very unorganized. Still a very old fashion company doesn't really like changes when most of the employee here are younger.

title: Very old-school
pros: Fair pay, beautiful office, cold brew on tap
cons: The staff dress is business professional, even post-covid and even for those who are not customer-facing. It's a bit dated. There are a lot of policy roadblocks that make efficiency difficult. Promotions are only given in January. Not very forward-thinking in terms of culture

title: Middle mgmt
pros: 1. Good pay 2. Understanding with personal situations 3. Flexible hours
cons: Gave out rules and policies during an unprecedented time during pandemic and didn’t follow them and even made threats and unlawful ultimatums to their employees when said employee followed those exact rules.

title: Desktop Support Analyst
pros: Company is enthusiastic about the work. There is a lot of room to grow at the company learning may different skills beyond what you expected to learn
cons: The ability to move up in the company can be difficult. The company is growing but the space in which they occupy is not.

title: Good Job
pros: Good company culture for the most part. Company is run well financially, so there is stability.
cons: Technology is a bit outdated, so this makes things take a little longer. Some perks are only offered to certain offices and not others.

title: Good run
pros: Benefits are okay for the here and now but not for the future
cons: No retirement concerns if you work out in the field. Only VP's get a pension

title: SF office is a nice place to work but can be old fashioned
pros: - Good hours (40 flat) - Nice people. Most managers are understanding - Work is fairly challenging but not too stressful
cons: - Old fashioned atmosphere resistant to change - Pay is kind of low - Upward mobility is limited for some positions

title: great place to work
pros: Great people to work with. Everyone is friendly and polite. Very healthy corporate culture.
cons: Upper management is a bit old-fashioned. Has a hard time understanding the millennial employee.

title: It was great until it wasn't
pros: Great people, great mentors, great opportunities.
cons: Pay is less than other companies because you get to work for the reputation, very old school corporate style, not a lot of growth opportunity

title: Great Company, Great People, Stagnant
pros: 10/10 organization and people to learn from. Impressive leadership and systems in place.
cons: Underpaid. As long as you know that going in, don’t expect to be surprised by the small comp increases every year or even in promotion years.

title: Good Company
pros: good reputable company to have on resume. encourages employees to continue learning by taking classes. great team.

title: Company structure skewed
pros: Day to day contacts within company are very nice and professional. Smaller managers are reasonable but can be very different between portfolios. Great amount of time off as well as summer hours. Great place to start out in the property management field.
cons: Red tape is everywhere. Much more focus on policies and procedures than going out and improving assets and retaining tenants. Very clear that it is WHO you know and not WHAT you know that will get you noticed in such a big company. If you don't toot your own horn once in awhile then no one else will. Majority of the employees have the mindset of using the company to get ahead in the field but do not plan on staying with the company for the long haul.

title: Corporate company with little opportunity for growth
pros: Well known in real estate industry, exposure to many departments
cons: Do not promote from within, no opportunity for advancement, annual review process is very time consuming to only have the same result of a very small raise and no title change, office management treats employees like children.
